chapter.htmlHeader: What clinical features are associated with hearing loss?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Clinical features associated with hearing loss vary widely depending on underlying cause:

  • Conductive hearing loss occurs as a result of obstruction or damage to the outer or middle ear which can often be visualised on examination. For example:
    • Cerumen impaction
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Earwax.
    • Otitis externa
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Otitis externa.
    • Necrotising otitis externa (previously known as malignant otitis externa)
      • Necrotising otitis externa is a life-threatening invasive bacterial infection involving the external ear canal and skull base — it is a complication of otitis externa.
      • Ear pain (which may disturb sleep) and discharge which persists despite treatment in people with immunosuppression or diabetes is suggestive of necrotising otitis externa.
      • Early identification and appropriate treatment are essential.
    • Otitis media
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Otitis media - acute.
    • Tympanic membrane perforation
      • History of acute trauma (for example head injury or penetrating ear injury from a cotton bud), barotrauma (for example due to scuba diving or explosive noise) or recent/recurrent otitis media.
      • There may be a visible defect in the tympanic membrane — small perforations may be difficult to visualise.
      • Blood may be present in the ear canal.
    • Middle ear effusion
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Otitis media - acute and Otitis media with effusion.
    • Otosclerosis
      • Typically presents with gradual-onset, bilateral, painless hearing loss in adults aged 30–50 years.
      • Symptoms may be unilateral and tinnitus may or may not be present.
      • There may be a family history of hearing loss.
      • The ear canal and tympanic membrane usually appear normal.
    • Cholesteatoma
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Cholesteatoma.
    • Glomus tumour
      • Typically presents with pulsatile tinnitus, a feeling of fullness in the ear and hearing loss.
      • A reddish blue mass may be visible behind a normal looking tympanic membrane.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss occurs as a result of abnormalities in the cochlea or other structures in the neural pathway from the inner ear to the auditory cortex. On examination, no abnormalities may be visible on otoscopy but associated symptoms such as vertigo or neurological signs may be present. For example:
    • Age-related hearing loss (presbycusis)
      • Typically presents with slowly progressive bilateral high-frequency hearing loss after the age of 50–60 years.
      • The person may be unaware of hearing loss and presentation prompted by friends or family who have noticed increasing television volume or difficulty hearing conversation.
      • Examination is usually normal.
    • Noise-related hearing loss
      • History of previous exposure to persistent high levels of noise or sudden loud noises (such as machinery, gunfire or loud music).
      • May be associated with tinnitus.
      • Examination is usually normal.
    • Sudden sensorineural hearing loss
      • Sudden onset of unilateral or bilateral hearing loss within 72 hours.
      • May be associated with tinnitus, ear fullness or pressure, and vertigo.
      • Examination is usually normal.
    • Labyrinthitis
      • Hearing loss associated with tinnitus, a sensation of pressure or fullness in the ear and vertigo.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Vertigo.
    • Meniere's disease
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Meniere's disease.
    • Vestibular schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma)
      • A slow growing, benign tumour (usually arising from Schwann cells in the vestibulocochlear nerve sheath) which causes hearing loss due to compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve.
      • Typically presents with gradual onset, unilateral hearing loss which may be associated with tinnitus and/or vertigo.
      • Ear examination is usually normal.
      • Neurological symptoms and signs may be present if tumour is advanced and has extended into the posterior cranial fossa causing cerebellar/brainstem compression.
      • In patients with known neurofibromatosis acoustic neuromas are often bilateral.
    • Ototoxin exposure
      • History of exposure to ototoxic drugs or industrial toxins — hearing loss is typically dose dependent and develops over weeks.
      • Ear examination is usually normal.
    • Infection such as meningitis, measles, shingles (Ramsay Hunt syndrome) and mumps.
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Measles, Meningitis - bacterial meningitis and meningococcal disease, Mumps and Shingles.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The information on clinical features associated with hearing loss are based on clinical guidelines Adult patients with severe-to-profound unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Clinical practice guidelines [American Academy of Audiology, 2015] and Hearing loss in adults: assessment and management [NICE, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [Stachler, 2012; Edmiston, 2013; Cunningham, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018; Fishman, 2018; Michels, 2019].
